keywords: Columbia River Basin, Anadromous salmonids, Endangered Species Act (ESA), Monitoring strategy, Water quality attributes (temperature, turbidity, conductivity, pH, dissolved oxygen, nitrogen, phosphorus)
abstract:
The text discusses the need for an effective monitoring strategy to address the declining populations of anadromous salmonids in the Columbia River Basin, which are now protected under the Endangered Species Act (ESA). The current data collected from existing monitoring programs are not sufficient for ESA assessments and recovery planning due to their lack of reliability and adequacy.

To address this issue, a comprehensive strategy is proposed that includes continuously monitoring seven key water quality attributes at integrator sites, which are downstream ends of each population or subpopulation. These attributes include temperature, turbidity, conductivity, pH, dissolved oxygen, nitrogen, and phosphorus. Data is collected weekly for temperature and daily maximums, while seasonal measurements of nitrogen and phosphorus are achieved by collecting monthly grab samples at these sites.

Water quality monitoring stations are coupled with flow gauges operated by the USGS or WDOE to assess the effect of stream flow upon water quality attributes. Accuracies of the water quality instruments meet Data Quality Level A, as defined by the Oregon Watershed Plan Water Quality Monitoring Technical Guidebook (2001).

This approach is crucial because it allows for comprehensive assessments of water quality at multiple spatial scales, required by the ESA, from specific reaches to populations and Evolutionary Significant Units (ESUs). Continuous monitoring also helps reduce uncertainties surrounding the declines and provides valuable data for developing strategies to reverse this trend.
